Federal Court of Canada
Trial Division
Dubé, J.
February 7, 2001.
Counsel:
Kanki Wignarajah, for the applicant;
Lara Speirs, for the respondent.
Solicitors of Record:
Kanki Wignarajah, Toronto, Ontario, for the applicant;
Morris Rosenberg, Deputy Attorney General of Canada, Ottawa, Ontario, for the respondent.
Summary:
This case is unedited, therefore contains no summary. This case was originally cited as [2001] F.T.R. TBEd. FE.112.

[1]
Dubé, J.
: The Applicant seek an extension of time to bring an application for judicial review of the decision of the Canadian Human Rights Commission (the "Commission") dated June 26, 2000 dismissing the Applicant's complaint against the Immigration and Refugee Board of discriminating practice on the basis of race and/or national or ethnic origin contrary to s. 7 of the
Canadian Human Rights Act
. The Applicant allegedly became aware of the decision only around the beginning of September, 2000. On October 12, 2000, the Applicant's solicitor requested a copy of the decision which the Commission forwarded on November 29, 2000. The instant motion for an extension of time was filed on January 12, 2001.

[2]
The Federal Court of Appeal in
 <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  (C.A.) at 272 established the principles applicable to the grant of an extension. The Federal Court Trial Division has consistently interpreted the factors set out in <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> as creating a two part test that must be satisfied in order for an extension of time to be granted:
First, there must be a reasonable justification for the delay throughout the whole period of the delay and, second, the Applicant must have a reasonable chance of success in his case. The Applicant must satisfy both tests. ( <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  at 134 and
 <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  at 105.

[3]
In my view, the Applicant has not met the first test. The affidavit in support of his application is merely the affidavit of an assistant in the law offices of his solicitors. The affidavit is very thin and carries little weight. Her paragraph 4 reads as follows:
4. Mr. Berkeley advised me and I verily believe that he first became aware of the decision of the CHRC in or around the beginning of September, 2000 when he was advised of the decision by J.R. Richards, a staff lawyer at the African Canadian Legal Clinic, Mr. Berkeley's previous counsel.

[4]
Of course Rule 81(1) of the
Federal Court Rules
allows statements as to the deponent's belief on motions. However, Rule 81(2) stipulates that such affidavits made on belief carry an adverse inference from the failure of a party to provide evidence of persons with personal knowledge of material facts. The best evidence is an important factor in a motion for an extension of time and more so where the date when the Applicant first became aware of a decision is a key issue. In this instance, the best evidence would have been that of the Applicant himself. The second best evidence would have been that of staff lawyer, J.R. Richards who informed him.

[5]
Moreover, there is no evidence in the Applicant's Motion Record demonstrating either due diligence in pursuing his application, or an intention to serve and file the application within the applicable time limit. And even if the evidence of the assistant was satisfactory, it does not cover the whole period.

[6]
On October 12, 2000 the Applicant's solicitor requested a copy of the decision. Waiting for reasons, in itself, is simply not an acceptable justification for failure to file an application.
 <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  (Fed. C.A.) at 191 wherein Mahoney J.A. state as follows (at p. 194):
That is the rationale for the countless decisions that waiting for reasons, in itself, is simply not an acceptable excuse for failure to file a s.28 application in time, e.g.
 <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> .

[7]
Furthermore, there is no justification whatsoever provided for the period from December 29, 2000 when the Commission forwarded a copy of the decision, and January 12, 2001 when the Applicant finally filed the instant application. Thus, it is not necessary to consider whether or not the Applicant has an arguable case. [see footnote 1]

[8]
Consequently, this application for an extension of time must be denied.
Footnote
1.
 <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  at 174.
[End of document]

legal_issues: Determining the standard for granting extensions of time for judicial review applications.
Evaluating the sufficiency of justification for delays in filing for judicial review.
Assessing the evidentiary weight of affidavits based on belief versus direct knowledge.
Considering whether requesting reasons for a decision constitutes reasonable justification for a delay in filing for judicial review.
Establishing the requirements for demonstrating due diligence in pursuing legal remedies within prescribed time limits.
factual_background: An applicant sought an extension of time to file an application for judicial review.
The application for judicial review concerned a decision by the Canadian Human Rights Commission (CHRC) dated June 26, 2000.
The CHRC decision dismissed the applicant's complaint of discriminatory practice against the Immigration and Refugee Board.
The complaint alleged discrimination based on race and/or national or ethnic origin, contrary to s. 7 of the Canadian Human Rights Act.
The applicant stated they became aware of the CHRC decision around the beginning of September 2000.
On October 12, 2000, the applicant's solicitor requested a copy of the CHRC decision.
The CHRC provided a copy of the decision on November 29, 2000.
The motion for an extension of time was filed on January 12, 2001.

Applicants: The applicant became aware of the Commission’s decision dismissing their complaint around the beginning of September 2000, as advised by J.R. Richards of the African Canadian Legal Clinic.
The applicant requested a copy of the decision from the Commission on October 12, 2000.
The applicant filed a motion for an extension of time on January 12, 2001, after receiving the decision from the Commission on November 29, 2000.
Respondents: The applicant has not provided a reasonable justification for the delay in bringing the application for judicial review.
The affidavit supporting the application is weak, being from a solicitor’s assistant and not the applicant or J.R. Richards who initially informed the applicant of the decision.
There is no evidence of due diligence in pursuing the application or an intention to file within the time limit.
Waiting for reasons for the decision is not an acceptable justification for the delay.
There is no justification for the delay between December 29, 2000 (when the decision was received) and January 12, 2001 (when the application was filed).

court_analysis: The court applied the two-part test for granting extensions of time established in Federal Court of Appeal precedent: (1) reasonable justification for the entire period of delay, and (2) a reasonable chance of success on the merits. The court found the applicant failed to satisfy the first part of the test.

The court found the affidavit supporting the extension request to be insufficient, specifically because it was from a solicitor’s assistant and not the applicant or the individual who initially informed the applicant of the decision (J.R. Richards). The court emphasized the importance of ‘best evidence’ in extension requests, particularly regarding the date awareness of the decision was established, and noted Rule 81(2) of the Federal Court Rules creates an adverse inference when evidence is not provided from those with personal knowledge.
The court rejected the justification of waiting for reasons for the delay, citing precedent stating that waiting for reasons alone is not an acceptable excuse for missing filing deadlines.

The court found no justification for the delay between receiving the decision from the Commission on November 29, 2000, and filing the extension request on January 12, 2001. Because the first part of the test was not met, the court determined it was unnecessary to assess the applicant’s chances of success on the merits.
final_outcome: Application for an extension of time was denied.
